posts.post_content:
I like the implications of this card.  
A removal enchantment that you don't really want to remove a creature with (but it can if you need it to).  
Seems decent in Limited.

posts.post_content: 1st pick in draft in my opinion. What we have here is removal, some burn, and a bit of control. The opponent may end up killing their own creature or sending it to attack to get rid of it, which are all in your favor. Great, awesome utility card. 5/5
posts.html:

Posted By: MechaKraken (9/30/2012 8:35:12 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: This was so great at prerelease. Dealing with small creatures and weakening big creatures while making the owner regret keeping them alive is amazing, especially at only 3 mana and one black. Throwing one on an opponent's [Lotleth Troll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lotleth Troll) was my favorite part of the weekend. "So you can either let that bomb die, or ditch your creature cards right now and make him too weak to be a big threat for a couple of turns and insure that I bleed you out for awhile." He picked the latter. Even by the time he finally wasted an Abrupt Decay on it, the Stab Wound had slowed down his game completely and gotten probably 10 life out of him. Awesomesauce
posts.html:

Posted By: cardraptor6 (10/1/2012 10:55:44 AM)

posts.post_content:
I chose Rakdos as my guild for the prerelease, and I opened **three** of these. Reading the card in the visual spoiler, I wasn't impressed, but as is so often the case, seeing the card in action taught me a new and healthy respect that I didn't have at first glance.   
  
It can kill a little guy, if you need that. It can cripple a big guy, if you need that. If, as with my Rakdos deck at the prerelease, you find your creature-based assault stalled, or facing a wall of bigger guys, then Stab Wound can serve as a way to get the final couple of points off of their life total. It created some interesting play decisions for me in a deck that was otherwise "play guy, attack, remove opponent creature, repeat", and I have to applaud the RtR team for creating such an interesting aura!   
  
Also, on a sillier note, because this is what went through my head upon first reading it:   
  
Centurion: "You know the penalty laid down by Roman law for harbouring a known criminal?"  
Matthias: "No."  
C: "Crucif... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

It can kill a little guy, if you need that. It can cripple a big guy, if you need that. If, as with my Rakdos deck at the prerelease, you find your creature-based assault stalled, or facing a wall of bigger guys, then Stab Wound can serve as a way to get the final couple of points off of their life total. It created some interesting play decisions for me in a deck that was otherwise "play guy, attack, remove opponent creature, repeat", and I have to applaud the RtR team for creating such an interesting aura!

Also, on a sillier note, because this is what went through my head upon first reading it:

Matthias: "No."

posts.post_content: Great card for limited. Leads to some interesting decisions for both you and your opponent. In general I think the card's better when it doesn't kill the creature cause you can often get your opponent to kill it off for you, using their own removal on their guy. Put this on their unleashed [thrill-kill assassin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=thrill-kill assassin) and laugh (also, don't unleash thrill-kill assassin against black)
posts.html:
